Miso-Butter Roast Chicken With Acorn Squash Panzanella

    "ingredients": [
        '1 (3½–4-lb.) whole chicken', '2¾ tsp. kosher salt, divided, plus more',
        '2 small acorn squash (about 3 lb. total)', '2 Tbsp. finely chopped sage',
        '1 Tbsp. finely chopped rosemary', '6 Tbsp. unsalted butter, melted, plus 3 Tbsp. room temperature',
        '¼ tsp. ground allspice', 'Pinch of crushed red pepper flakes', 'Freshly ground black pepper',
        '⅓ loaf good-quality sturdy white bread, torn into 1" pieces (about 2½ cups)',
        '2 medium apples (such as Gala or Pink Lady; about 14 oz. total), cored, cut into 1" pieces',
        '2 Tbsp. extra-virgin olive oil', '½ small red onion, thinly sliced',
        '3 Tbsp. apple cider vinegar', '1 Tbsp. white miso', '¼ cup all-purpose flour',
        '2 Tbsp. unsalted butter, room temperature', '¼ cup dry white wine',
        '2 cups unsalted chicken broth', '2 tsp. white miso', 'Kosher salt, freshly ground pepper'
    ],
    "instructions":
        1. Pat chicken dry with paper towels, season all over with 2 tsp. salt, and tie legs together with kitchen twine. Let sit at room temperature 1 hour.

        2. Meanwhile, halve squash and scoop out seeds. Run a vegetable peeler along ridges of squash halves to remove skin. Cut each half into ½""-thick wedges; arrange on a rimmed baking sheet.

        3. Combine sage, rosemary, and 6 Tbsp. melted butter in a large bowl; pour half of mixture over squash on baking sheet. Sprinkle squash with allspice, red pepper flakes, and ½ tsp. salt and season with black pepper; toss to coat.

        4. Add bread, apples, oil, and ¼ tsp. salt to remaining herb butter in bowl; season with black pepper and toss to combine. Set aside.
        Place onion and vinegar in a small bowl; season with salt and toss to coat. Let sit, tossing occasionally, until ready to serve.

        5. Place a rack in middle and lower third of oven; preheat to 425°F. Mix miso and 3 Tbsp. room-temperature butter in a small bowl until smooth. Pat chicken dry with paper towels, then rub or brush all over with miso butter. Place chicken in a large cast-iron skillet and roast on middle rack until an instant-read thermometer inserted into the thickest part of breast registers 155°F, 50–60 minutes. (Temperature will climb to 165°F while chicken rests.) Let chicken rest in skillet at least 5 minutes, then transfer to a plate; reserve skillet.

        6. Meanwhile, roast squash on lower rack until  mostly tender, about 25 minutes. Remove from oven and scatter reserved bread mixture over, spreading into as even a layer as you can manage. Return to oven and roast until bread is golden brown and crisp and apples are tender, about 15 minutes. Remove from oven, drain pickled onions, and toss to combine. Transfer to a serving dish.

        7. Using your fingers, mash flour and butter in a small bowl to combine.

        8. Set reserved skillet with chicken drippings over medium heat. You should have about ¼ cup, but a little over or under is all good. (If you have significantly more, drain off and set excess aside.) Add wine and cook, stirring often and scraping up any browned bits with a wooden spoon, until bits are loosened and wine is reduced by about half (you should be able to smell the wine), about 2 minutes. Add butter mixture; cook, stirring often, until a smooth paste forms, about 2 minutes. Add broth and any reserved drippings and cook, stirring constantly, until combined and thickened, 6–8 minutes. Remove from heat and stir in miso. Taste and season with salt and black pepper.

        9. Serve chicken with gravy and squash panzanella alongside.
------------------------------

Great choice! The recipe you've selected is Miso-Butter Roast Chicken With Acorn Squash Panzanella. Here are all the ingredients you will need for this recipe:

Ingredients:
- 1 (3½–4-lb.) whole chicken
- 2¾ tsp. kosher salt, divided, plus more
- 2 small acorn squash (about 3 lb. total)
- 2 Tbsp. finely chopped sage
- 1 Tbsp. finely chopped rosemary
- 6 Tbsp. unsalted butter, melted, plus 3 Tbsp. room temperature
- ¼ tsp. ground allspice
- Pinch of crushed red pepper flakes
- Freshly ground black pepper
- ⅓ loaf good-quality sturdy white bread, torn into 1" pieces (about 2½ cups)
- 2 medium apples (such as Gala or Pink Lady; about 14 oz. total), cored, cut into 1" pieces
- 2 Tbsp. extra-virgin olive oil
- ½ small red onion, thinly sliced
- 3 Tbsp. apple cider vinegar
- 1 Tbsp. white miso
- ¼ cup all-purpose flour
- 2 Tbsp. unsalted butter, room temperature
- ¼ cup dry white wine
- 2 cups unsalted chicken broth
- 2 tsp. white miso
- Kosher salt, freshly ground pepper

Please let me know when you're ready to begin with the step-by-step guidance.

In this step, you will be preparing the whole chicken for roasting:

1. Pat the chicken dry with paper towels: This helps to remove any excess moisture from the chicken, which will help the skin to crisp up during roasting.

2. Season all over with 2 tsp. salt: Sprinkle the salt evenly all over the chicken, ensuring it is seasoned on all sides. This will help to flavor the chicken throughout.

3. Tie legs together with kitchen twine: Tying the legs together helps the chicken to cook evenly and keeps its shape during roasting.

4. Let the seasoned chicken sit at room temperature for 1 hour: Allowing the chicken to sit at room temperature helps it to cook more evenly and ensures that it reaches the desired internal temperature.

Once you have completed these steps, please let me know if you have any questions or if you're ready to move on to the next step by saying 'next'.
can i use a different type of seasoning instead of salt for the chicken?

Yes, you can definitely use a different type of seasoning for the chicken if you prefer. You can experiment with different herbs and spices to customize the flavor of the roast chicken according to your taste preferences. Just ensure that the seasoning you choose complements the other flavors in the dish. Once you've decided on your seasoning, go ahead and season the chicken all over before proceeding to the next step. Let me know when you're ready to move on by saying 'next'.

In this step, you will be preparing the acorn squash for roasting. Here is a detailed explanation of the process:

1. Halve the squash: Cut the acorn squash in half lengthwise, and then scoop out the seeds using a spoon.

2. Remove the skin: Use a vegetable peeler to peel the skin off the ridges of the squash halves. This will help enhance the texture and appearance of the roasted squash.

3. Cut into wedges: Once the squash halves are peeled, cut each half into ½-inch thick wedges. This will help the squash cook evenly and caramelize nicely in the oven.

4. Arrange on a baking sheet: Place the squash wedges on a rimmed baking sheet in a single layer. This will ensure even roasting and caramelization of the squash.

After you have completed these steps, please let me know if you have any questions or if you're ready to proceed to the next step by saying 'next'.
can i leave the skin on the acorn squash for roasting, or is it necessary to peel it off?

Leaving the skin on the acorn squash is optional and can be a matter of personal preference. The skin of acorn squash is edible once roasted, and some people enjoy the texture and flavor it adds to the dish. However, peeling the squash before roasting can result in a smoother and more tender texture.

If you choose to leave the skin on, make sure to wash the squash thoroughly before cutting and roasting. If you prefer a softer texture or want to avoid the skin, peeling the squash as instructed in the recipe will ensure a more uniform and tender result. Feel free to decide based on your preference and proceed with the method that suits you best. Let me know if you have any more questions or if you're ready to move on by saying 'next'.
next

In this step, you will be preparing a flavorful herb butter mixture to coat the acorn squash before roasting. Here's a detailed explanation of the process:

1. Combine sage, rosemary, and 6 Tbsp. melted butter: In a large bowl, mix together the finely chopped sage, rosemary, and melted butter. This mixture will infuse the squash with aromatic herb flavors during roasting.

2. Pour half of the herb butter mixture over the squash: Drizzle half of the herb butter mixture over the acorn squash wedges on the baking sheet. Make sure to evenly distribute the mixture to coat the squash pieces.

3. Sprinkle with allspice, red pepper flakes, salt, and black pepper: Season the squash with the ground allspice, red pepper flakes, ½ tsp. salt, and black pepper. These seasonings will add depth of flavor and a hint of spice to the roasted squash.

4. Toss to coat: Gently toss the squash wedges with the herb butter mixture and seasonings until they are evenly coated. This ensures that the flavors are distributed evenly and that each piece is well seasoned.

Once you have completed these steps, please let me know if you have any questions or if you're ready to proceed by saying 'next'.
can i substitute dried sage and rosemary for fresh in the herb butter mixture?

Yes, you can substitute dried sage and rosemary for fresh in the herb butter mixture. When substituting dried herbs for fresh, the general rule of thumb is to use one-third of the amount specified for fresh herbs. This is because dried herbs are more concentrated in flavor than fresh ones.

For this recipe, you can use about 1 tablespoon of dried sage and 1 teaspoon of dried rosemary in place of the fresh herbs. Make sure to adjust the amounts according to your taste preference, as dried herbs can be more potent than fresh herbs.

Feel free to proceed with the substitution and continue with the preparation of the herb butter mixture for the acorn squash. Let me know if you have any more questions or when you're ready to move on by saying 'next'.
next

In this step, you will be preparing the components for the panzanella salad and pickled onions. Here's a detailed explanation of the process:

1. Add bread, apples, oil, and salt to the remaining herb butter: Combine torn pieces of bread, chopped apples, extra-virgin olive oil, and ¼ tsp. salt in the bowl with the remaining herb butter mixture. Season with black pepper and toss everything together to ensure the bread and apples are coated with the herb butter mixture. This will help to infuse the flavors and ensure even seasoning.

2. Set the bread and apple mixture aside: Once combined, set aside the bread and apple mixture for now. This mixture will be used later to create the panzanella salad, a delicious bread salad that complements the roast chicken.

3. Prepare the pickled onions: In a separate small bowl, place thinly sliced red onion and apple cider vinegar. Season with salt and toss the onions in the vinegar to coat them. Allow the onions to sit and marinate, tossing occasionally, until you are ready to serve the dish. Pickling the onions adds a tangy and flavorful element to the overall dish.

By following these steps, you will have the components ready for the salad and pickled onions to accompany the roast chicken. Please let me know if you have any questions or when you're ready to proceed by saying 'next'.
can i use a different type of vinegar for the pickled onions, or is apple cider vinegar essential for the flavor profile of the dish?

You can definitely experiment with different types of vinegar for the pickled onions if you prefer. While apple cider vinegar adds a distinct flavor profile with its slightly sweet and tangy notes, you can substitute it with other vinegars like white wine vinegar, red wine vinegar, or even balsamic vinegar based on your taste preferences.

Each vinegar will bring a unique flavor to the pickled onions, so feel free to choose one that complements the overall dish and suits your palate. Once you've decided on the vinegar you'd like to use, go ahead and prepare the pickled onions as instructed. Let me know if you have any more questions or when you're ready to proceed by saying 'next'.
next

In this step, you will be preparing the roast chicken using a flavorful miso butter mixture. Here's a detailed explanation of the process:

1. Preheat the oven: Place a rack in the middle and lower third of the oven and preheat it to 425°F. Ensuring the oven is properly preheated will help the chicken cook evenly and achieve a crispy skin.

2. Mix miso and room-temperature butter: In a small bowl, combine the white miso paste and 3 tablespoons of room-temperature butter. Mix them together until you have a smooth and well-blended miso butter mixture.

3. Prepare the chicken: Pat the chicken dry with paper towels to remove any excess moisture. This step helps the skin of the chicken to crisp up during roasting.

4. Coat the chicken with miso butter: Rub or brush the miso butter mixture all over the chicken, ensuring it is evenly coated. This will infuse the chicken with rich umami flavor from the miso while adding moisture and flavor.

5. Roast the chicken: Place the miso-butter-coated chicken in a large cast-iron skillet and roast it in the preheated oven on the middle rack. Roast the chicken until an instant-read thermometer inserted into the thickest part of the breast registers 155°F, which should take around 50-60 minutes. The internal temperature will continue to rise to 165°F as the chicken rests.

6. Let the chicken rest: Once the chicken reaches the desired temperature, let it rest in the skillet for at least 5 minutes. Resting allows the juices to redistribute, resulting in a juicier and more flavorful chicken.

7. Transfer the chicken: After resting, transfer the roast chicken to a plate. Remember to reserve the skillet, as it will be used later to make the gravy.

Once you've completed these steps, please let me know if you have any questions or if you're ready to proceed with the next step by saying 'next'.
can i use a different type of butter for the miso butter mixture, or does it need to be room-temperature butter specifically?

It is important to use room-temperature butter specifically for the miso butter mixture in this recipe. Room-temperature butter is soft and easier to mix with the miso paste, creating a smooth and well-blended mixture. This ensures that the flavors are evenly distributed and that the miso butter coats the chicken effectively during roasting.

Using butter that is too cold may result in clumps and uneven distribution of the miso paste, affecting the flavor and texture of the dish. Therefore, it is recommended to use room-temperature butter for the best results.

Once you're ready to move on, please let me know by saying 'next'.
next

In this step, you will be finishing the roasting process for the acorn squash and the bread mixture to prepare the panzanella salad. Here's a detailed explanation of the process:

1. Roast the squash: While the chicken is resting, continue roasting the acorn squash on the lower rack of the oven until it is mostly tender, which should take about 25 minutes. This additional roasting time allows the squash to caramelize and develop a rich flavor.

2. Add the bread mixture: Once the squash is mostly tender, remove the baking sheet from the oven and scatter the reserved bread and apple mixture over the squash. Spread the mixture into an even layer as best as you can to ensure even roasting.

3. Return to the oven: Place the baking sheet back into the oven and continue roasting the squash and bread mixture until the bread is golden brown and crisp, and the apples are tender. This should take about 15 minutes, resulting in a flavorful and textured panzanella salad.

4. Remove from the oven: Once the bread is golden brown and crisp, and the apples are tender, remove the baking sheet from the oven. Drain the pickled onions that have been marinating and toss them with the roasted squash and bread mixture to combine all the flavors.

5. Transfer to a serving dish: Finally, transfer the combined squash panzanella mixture to a serving dish to be served alongside the roast chicken and gravy.

By following these steps, you will have a delicious and flavorful panzanella salad ready to accompany the roast chicken. Please let me know if you have any questions or when you're ready to proceed by saying 'next'.
can i use a different type of bread for the bread mixture in this recipe?

Yes, you can definitely experiment with different types of bread for the bread mixture in this recipe. While the recipe calls for a good-quality sturdy white bread torn into 1-inch pieces, you can choose to use other types of bread such as whole wheat, sourdough, or even multigrain bread based on your preference.

Different types of bread will bring varying flavors and textures to the dish, so feel free to select a bread that complements the overall flavors and suits your taste. Just ensure that the bread you choose is sturdy enough to hold up in the dish and can absorb the flavors of the herb butter mixture when roasted.

Once you've decided on the type of bread you'd like to use, go ahead and prepare the bread mixture as instructed in the recipe. Let me know when you're ready to continue or if you have any more questions by saying 'next'.

In this step, you will be creating a smooth paste by mashing flour and butter together in a small bowl. Here's a detailed explanation of the process:

1. Combine flour and butter: Place the all-purpose flour and room-temperature unsalted butter in a small bowl.

2. Mash with fingers: Using your fingers, work the flour and butter together by pressing and rubbing them against each other. The goal is to incorporate the flour into the butter until a smooth paste-like consistency is achieved.

3. Ensure thorough mixing: Continue mashing and mixing the flour and butter until there are no visible lumps of flour remaining, and the mixture is well combined. The resulting paste should be smooth and homogeneous.

4. Set aside: Once you have achieved a smooth paste, set it aside. This flour and butter mixture will be used later in the recipe to help thicken and flavor the gravy.

By following these steps, you will have prepared the flour and butter mixture needed for the gravy. Please let me know if you have any questions or when you're ready to proceed by saying 'next'.
can i use margarine instead of unsalted butter for this step?

Yes, you can use margarine as a substitute for unsalted butter in this step of the recipe. Margarine can often be used as a substitute for butter in various cooking applications, including creating a flour and butter mixture for thickening sauces and gravies. Just ensure that the margarine you use is suitable for cooking and baking purposes.

When using margarine instead of butter, keep in mind that margarine may contain added salt and water content, which can affect the flavor and consistency of the final dish. Adjusting the seasoning as needed and monitoring the consistency of the mixture during cooking can help ensure a successful outcome.

Feel free to proceed with using margarine in place of unsalted butter for this step. Let me know if you have any more questions or when you're ready to continue by saying 'next'.
next

In this step, you will be creating a flavorful gravy using the drippings from the roast chicken. Here's a detailed explanation of the process:

1. Set the reserved skillet over medium heat: Place the skillet that was used to roast the chicken with the drippings over medium heat on the stovetop. The drippings will add rich flavor to the gravy.

2. Add wine and deglaze the skillet: Pour in the dry white wine and stir, scraping up any browned bits from the bottom of the skillet with a wooden spoon. This process, known as deglazing, helps release the flavorful browned bits and incorporates them into the gravy.

3. Reduce the wine: Cook the wine, stirring often, until it is reduced by about half. This will intensify the flavors and create a concentrated base for the gravy.

4. Add the flour and butter mixture: Once the wine is reduced, add the flour and butter mixture you prepared earlier. Stir the mixture into the skillet and cook, stirring often, until a smooth paste forms. This will help thicken the gravy.

5. Incorporate broth and reserved drippings: Pour in the unsalted chicken broth and any reserved drippings from the roasted chicken. Stir constantly to combine and allow the mixture to thicken and develop flavor.

6. Stir in miso: Once the gravy is thickened to your desired consistency, remove the skillet from the heat and stir in the white miso paste. This will add a savory umami flavor to the gravy.

7. Taste and season: Finally, taste the gravy and adjust the seasoning as needed with salt and black pepper. This step ensures that the gravy is well-balanced and seasoned to your liking.

By following these steps, you will have prepared a delicious miso-infused gravy to serve with the roast chicken. Please let me know if you have any questions or when you're ready to proceed by saying 'next'.
can i substitute vegetable broth for the unsalted chicken broth in this recipe?

Yes, you can substitute vegetable broth for unsalted chicken broth in this recipe. Vegetable broth can be a suitable alternative for those looking to make the dish vegetarian or if chicken broth is not available. The vegetable broth will still provide a flavorful base for the gravy and complement the other ingredients in the dish.

When using vegetable broth as a substitute, consider the flavor profile it brings and adjust the seasoning as needed to ensure the gravy is well-balanced. Feel free to proceed with using vegetable broth in place of unsalted chicken broth for this recipe.

In this final step, you will bring everything together to serve the Miso-Butter Roast Chicken With Acorn Squash Panzanella:

1. Serve the roast chicken: Place the roast chicken on a serving platter or individual plates, ready to be enjoyed.

2. Pour the miso-infused gravy: Drizzle the miso gravy over the roast chicken to add extra flavor and moisture to the dish.

3. Serve the squash panzanella: Transfer the roasted acorn squash panzanella to a serving dish or plate alongside the roast chicken. The flavorful combination of squash, bread, apples, and pickled onions creates a delicious side dish.

4. Garnish and present: You can garnish the dish with additional herbs, a sprinkle of freshly ground black pepper, or a drizzle of olive oil for a finishing touch.

5. Enjoy: Invite your guests to savor the Miso-Butter Roast Chicken With Acorn Squash Panzanella, a delightful combination of flavors and textures that make for a satisfying meal.

Once you have served the dish, feel free to enjoy the delicious meal you've prepared! If you have any more questions or need further assistance, please let me know.
can i substitute the acorn squash with a different type of squash for the panzanella?

Yes, you can substitute the acorn squash with a different type of squash for the panzanella if you prefer. Some squash varieties that can work well in a panzanella salad include butternut squash, delicata squash, or even kabocha squash. Each type of squash will bring its own unique flavor and texture to the dish, so feel free to choose one that you enjoy or have available.

When substituting squash varieties, consider factors such as sweetness, firmness, and cooking time to ensure that the squash complements the other ingredients in the panzanella salad. Once you've selected your preferred squash, you can proceed with roasting and incorporating it into the dish.
